## Calendrier

```{r}
check <- character(0)
schedule <- schedule_df %>%
  rowwise() %>%
  mutate(
    day = case_match(
      session,
      1 ~ "Lun",
      2 ~ "Mer",
      3 ~ "Jeu"
    ),
    qmd_file = ifelse(
      identical(
        str_subset(
          list.files("slides", pattern = "qmd", full.names = TRUE),
          pattern = sprintf("lec-%1$.2d-%2$x", week, session)
        ),
        check
      ),
      NA,
      str_subset(
        list.files("slides", pattern = "qmd", full.names = TRUE),
        pattern = sprintf("lec-%1$.2d-%2$x", week, session)
      )
    ),
    lecture_file = ifelse(!is.na(qmd_file),
      gsub("qmd", "slides.html", qmd_file),
      NA
    ),
    notes_file = ifelse(!is.na(qmd_file),
      gsub("qmd", "notes.html", qmd_file),
      NA
    ), ,
    lecture = !is.na(lecture_file)
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  mutate(
    Material = case_when(
      session != 3 & lecture == TRUE ~ glue("<a class='fa fa-display' href='{lecture_file}' target='_blank'></a> <a class='fa fa-note-sticky' href='{notes_file}' target='_blank'></a>"),
      session == 3 ~ reading,
      TRUE ~ ""
    ),
    Topic = ifelse(is.na(topic), "", topic),
    Assessment = ifelse(is.na(assessment), "", assessment),
    Reading = ifelse(is.na(reading), "", reading),
    Date = as.Date(
      case_when(
        week == 21 ~ ymd(dat$date_read),
        week == 31 ~ ymd(dat$date_final),
        day == "Mer" & week <= 6 ~ ymd(dat$date_start) + weeks(week - 1),
        day == "Mer" & week > 6 ~ ymd(dat$date_start) + weeks(week),
        day == "Lun" & week <= 6 ~ ymd(dat$date_start) + weeks(week - 1) - days(2),
        day == "Lun" & week > 6 ~ ymd(dat$date_start) + weeks(week) - days(2),
        day == "Jeu" & week <= 6 ~ ymd(dat$date_start) + weeks(week - 1) + days(1),
        day == "Jeu" & week > 6 ~ ymd(dat$date_start) + weeks(week) + days(1)
      )
    ),
    wk = ifelse((week %% 2) == 0, "a", ifelse(week < 20, "b", "c"))
  ) %>%
  select(Date, Topic, Material, Assessment, week, wk) %>%
  arrange(Date) %>%
  mutate(Date = case_match(week,
    21 ~ NA,
    31 ~ NA,
    .default = Date
  )) %>%
  rename(
    Sujet = "Topic",
    Doc = "Material",
    `√âvaluation` = "Assessment"
  )

midsem_break <- 6 # after which week

schedule |>
  gt() |>
  cols_hide(c(week, wk)) |>
  fmt_markdown(columns = c("Sujet", "Doc", "√âvaluation")) |>
  fmt_date(
    columns = Date,
    date_style = "MMMd",
    locale = "en"
  ) |>
  data_color(
    columns = wk,
    method = "factor",
    target_columns = everything(),
    palette = c("lightblue", "grey80", "pink")
  ) |>
  #  tab_row_group(
  #    label = "Reading week",
  #    rows = (midsem_break * 2 + 2):26
  #  ) |>
  # row_group_order(groups = c(NA, "Reading week")) |>
  cols_width(
    Date ~ px(50),
    `√âvaluation` ~ px(20)
  ) |>
  sub_missing(missing_text = "") |>
  tab_options(
    table.width = pct(100),
  )
```

## √Ä propos des diapositives {{< fa display >}} et notes {{< fa note-sticky >}}

### Diapositives {{< fa display >}}

Diapositives en `revealjs` format (html). Si vous les souhaitez en format pdf (*Remarque : il se peut que vous perdiez certaines fonctionnalit√©s ou certains contenus en raison des onglets et des sections de d√©filement.*) :

1. Ouvrez les diapositives dans votre navigateur √† partir d'un lien sur cette page
2. Appuyez sur `e` pour passer en mode d'exportation PDF (*`?print-pdf` devrait appara√Ætre vers la fin de l'url et des bordures blanches devraient appara√Ætre.*)
3. Ouvrez la bo√Æte de dialogue d'impression du navigateur (CTRL/CMD+P).
4. Modifiez l'option `Destination` en `Save as PDF`.
5. Modifier le `Layout` √† `Landscape`.
6. Modifier le `Margins` √† `None`.
7. Activez l'option Graphiques d'arri√®re-plan (si vous le souhaitez)
8. Cliquez sur Enregistrer üéâ

Contenu des diapositives au format html sous la forme d'un fichier t√©l√©chargeable autonome et comprenant des onglets et des sections de d√©filement.

Plus important encore, les notes ont les outils de commentaire et d'annotation activ√©s via [https://hypothes.is/](https://hypothes.is/). Si vous cr√©ez un compte gratuit, vous pouvez annoter et commenter des diapositives et partager vos annotations/commentaires avec le public ou via des groupes priv√©s ou publics.
